body: Try not modifying the network first to isolate the error source.

I was thinking this use case is a bit more involved than simply modifying yolo to a custom multiple class system.

YOLO uses separate objectness and class confidence scores. In the limiting condition of a single class, these two values are redundant, and training in this way would be using a suboptimal network structure and loss function.

It should still be possible if course though. Can you figure out which of your indices is causing the error: b, a, gi, gj, or tc? The error is telling you that one of these is trying to index a value of 1 when the dimension size is 1 (and thus only indexible by a 0).
Thanks for your answer. Leaving the network as is leads to another error, where the tensor sizes are not compatible. However, the index causing problems is tc.
tc is the target class. Python is zero indexed, so if you have only one class the target class should always be zero. It looks like you could be passing in ones.
Thanks. Unfortunately, I didn't have time to test the model after your suggestions. I may try later and update the issue if needed.

I was curious about training a model with a single class after I've read another issue at this repository, here are my quick experiences:
- changing the parameter of classes to 18 in `yolov3.cfg` is a must :)
- based on the first question at this issue, in `utils/utils.py line 281`, change the `tc` to `0`
- in `test.py line 93-94` `AP_accum_count` and `AP_accum` calculation is not working

Other than this, I believe (if it works for multiple classes, then) it works for a single class.
@glenn-jocher thanks a lot, I will give feedback on the custom training I wanted to do as soon as I have the time.

Single-class training guide is finished. Example shows excellent results.
https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/wiki/Example:-Train-Single-Class

@glenn-jocher 

I've encountered the same issue in running train.py on custom classes (80 coco classes + 1 additional class). Error message copied below. This error appears upon completion of 280 batches with size = 16. 

Could you advise what I might fix? Let me know if you need more info please. Thanks!

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "train.py", line 203, in <module>
    var=opt.var,
  File "train.py", line 127, in train
    loss = model(imgs.to(device), targets, var=var)
  File "/home/usr/anaconda3/envs/test_env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/torch/nn/modules/module.py", line 489, in __call__
    result = self.forward(*input, **kwargs)
  File "/home/usr/yolov3/models.py", line 250, in forward
    x, *losses = module[0](x, img_size, targets, var)
  File "/home/usr/anaconda3/envs/test_env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/torch/nn/modules/module.py", line 489, in __call__
    result = self.forward(*input, **kwargs)
  File "/home/usr/yolov3/models.py", line 153, in forward
    txy, twh, mask, tcls = build_targets(targets, self.anchor_vec, self.nA, self.nC, nG)
  File "/home/usr/yolov3/utils/utils.py", line 281, in build_targets
    tcls[b, a, gj, gi, tc] = 1
RuntimeError: index -9223372036854775808 is out of bounds for dim with size 81
```

@ehhuh I would follow the directions in this tutorial, but adjust for 81 classes as appropriate.
https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/wiki/Example:-Train-Single-Class

@glenn-jocher  thanks! I did follow the tutorial - just double checked all config and data files and confirmed they conform. As a side note, the config/data/names files all work on the darknet (have trained with these files and wanted to use your repo to compare results/performance). 

Anything else I might try? Thanks so much again!

@ehhuh the errror is saying that `tc` is not between 0 and 80, the limits that your classes should be if you have 81 classes. You should set a breakpoint at the error message (`line 281, in build_targets`) to figure out why `tc` is not between these values. In your target files remember the class numbers are zero indexed, so you should never have a class below zero or above 80 if you have 81 classes.
